item.title: Explosion in Turkish Capital Kills at Least 27, Officials Say
item.description: The blast in Ankara was believed to have been caused by a car bomb. It came three weeks after a deadly bombing on a military convoy in the same city.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: People helped an injured person on the ground near the explosion site in Ankara, Turkey, on Sunday.

item.title: Anti-Immigrant Party Makes Gains in German Elections, Exit Polls Suggest
item.description: As three states voted, the ascendance of a far-right party pointed to the strains from Chancellor Angela Merkel’s policy of accepting refugees.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Winfried Kretschmann, the incumbent governor of the German state of Baden-Württemberg, spoke to the media outside a polling station in Sigmaringen on Sunday.

item.title: Gunmen Carry Out Fatal Attacks at Hotels in Ivory Coast
item.description: Gunmen stormed resort hotels in Ivory Coast on Sunday, piercing the calm that has prevailed in recent years.
item.dc:creator: LOUCOUMANE COULIBALY and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: A soldier comforted a wounded boy in Grand Bassam, Ivory Coast, on Sunday.

item.title: Germanwings Crash Inquiry Urges Stricter Oversight of Pilots’ Mental Health
item.description: French aviation officials called for guidelines that could require doctors to report pilots whose psychological condition might imperil public safety.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
item.description: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A miner for the Longmay Mining Group, in Heilongjiang Province, China. Mining conglomerates are struggling with a surplus of workers and production capacity.

item.title: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
item.description: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A miner for the Longmay Mining Group, in Heilongjiang Province, China. Mining conglomerates are struggling with a surplus of workers and production capacity.

item.title: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
item.description: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A miner for the Longmay Mining Group, in Heilongjiang Province, China. Mining conglomerates are struggling with a surplus of workers and production capacity.

item.title: Culture Gap Impedes U.S. Business Efforts for Trade With Cuba
item.description: As President Obama prepares to visit Cuba this month, the lack of trade with the former foe threatens to sap momentum from the process of building relations.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: The seafront outside the American Embassy in Havana. Cuba has made it clear that it will not alter the way it does business to suit American needs.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Where the Soldiers Are Scarier Than the Crocodiles
item.description: A catastrophe is unfolding in South Sudan, and while we may not be able to stop it, we need to try.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Two Nuer boys play with guns constructed of clay.

item.title: Opinion: How Saudi Arabia Turned Its Greatest Weapon on Itself
item.description: For decades, the kingdom used oil prices to wage economic war on its enemies. Now it’s the big casualty.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW SCOTT COOPER
item.media:description: Outside an Aramco oil field complex in Saudi Arabia in 2003.

item.title: In Hail of Bullets and Fire, North Korea Killed Official Who Wanted Reform
item.description: A biography of Jang Song-thaek, the uncle of North Korea’s leader, depicts a reformist political fixture who became the most famous victim of his nephew’s purges.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, right, and his uncle Jang Song-thaek, who was widely considered the second most powerful figure in the country, at a military parade in Pyongyang in February 2012. Mr. Jang was convicted of treason and executed the next year.

item.title: After Rockets Fired From Gaza, Israelis Strike Hamas Bases
item.description: Israel targeted Hamas bases after militants fired rockets toward Israeli border communities late Friday. Shrapnel from Israeli attack kills 2 children.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: State of Terror: To Maintain Supply of Sex Slaves, ISIS Pushes Birth Control
item.description: Modern methods allow the Islamic State to keep up its systematic rape of captives under medieval codes.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: M., who was kidnapped and sold into sexual slavery and raped repeatedly by fighters with the Islamic State, wept as she prepared to leave for Germany in January under a resettlement program. She was in a camp for internally displaced Yazidis near Dohuk, Iraq.

item.title: China Weighs Letting Banks Sell Bad Debt to Investors
item.description: The tentative proposal, which officials said on Saturday would be modest in scale, is meant to help alleviate one of the major drags on China’s economy.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Zhou Xiaochuan, the head of the People’s Bank of China, said on Saturday that the securitization program would be modest and closely monitored.

item.title: Sinosphere: China Wrestles With Draft Law on Nongovernmental Organizations
item.description: There are questions as to if the government is reconsidering whether the legislation could crimp international cooperation in areas it cares about.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Volunteers for Roots & Shoots, the Jane Goodall Institute’s youth program, planting tree saplings at a farm in Inner Mongolia in 2011 to help fight desertification.

item.title: World Briefing: Israeli Airstrike on Hamas Base Kills Boy Nearby, Gaza Officials Say
item.description: The Israeli attack was a response to a barrage of rockets fired into Israel by militants in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World’s Oldest Man, a Confectioner From Poland, Survived Auschwitz
item.description: Israel Kristal, 112, lost his family in the Holocaust and weighed 81 pounds when the Allies freed him from a labor camp. Now, he has been declared the world’s oldest man.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:credit: Dvir Rosen/Guinness World Records, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Israel Kristal, center, the world’s oldest man, with Marco Frigatti, right, head of records for Guinness World Records, in Haifa, Israel.

item.title: Hague Appeals Panel Voids Conviction of Lebanese TV Executive
item.description: Karma al-Khayat had been fined 10,000 euros for defying a court order to remove information about confidential witnesses from her TV station’s website.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: White House Backs Off From Obama’s Critique of Cameron
item.description: President Obama unloaded on a number of American allies: Britain, France, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and other Persian Gulf countries.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Peace Event Hosts Wives of South Sudan Leaders Tied to Rape
item.description: The spouses of two South Sudanese rivals accused by the United Nations of using sexual violence as a war tactic are participating in a United Nations panel.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
